case_vignette: A 37-year-old man comes to the emergency department with his wife because of a 3-day history of severe pain in his right arm. He also reports that he cannot move his right arm. The symptoms began after the patient woke up one morning, having slept on his side. He is otherwise healthy. He works as a waiter and says that he feels exhausted from working several night shifts per week. He adds that he “can barely keep his eyes open” when looking after their daughter the next day. Since the onset of the pain, he has been unable to work and is fully dependent on his wife, who took an extra shift to make enough money to pay their monthly bills. The patient appears relaxed but only allows himself to be examined after his wife convinces him. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows 1/5 muscle strength in the right arm. Reflexes are normal. He has no sensation to light touch over the entire right arm and forearm. When a pin prick test is conducted, the patient rapidly withdraws the right arm.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have severe pain in my right arm and I can't move it.
How long have you been experiencing this pain and immobility?
It's been 3 days since it started.
Have you had any recent injuries or trauma to your arm or neck?
No, it just started after I woke up one morning.
Do you have any weakness or numbness in your face or any other part of your body?
No, just in my right arm.
Have you experienced any recent neck pain or stiffness?
No, I haven't.
Are you experiencing any other symptoms such as difficulty speaking, changes in vision, or problems with balance?
No, I'm just really tired and can barely keep my eyes open after my night shifts.
Do you have a history of repetitive movements or overuse of your right arm, such as in your job or hobbies?
Yes, I work as a waiter.
Are there any other medical conditions that you have been diagnosed with previously?
No, I'm otherwise healthy.
What is your age and sex?
I'm a 37-year-old man.
Have you taken any medications or tried any treatments for your arm pain since it started?
No, I have not taken any medications or tried any treatments.
Have you noticed any swelling, redness, or warmth in the affected arm?
No, there's no swelling, redness, or warmth.
Do you have any history of heart disease or any cardiovascular symptoms?
No, I don't have any history of heart disease.
Does your arm pain worsen with movement or at rest, and does changing positions help?
Since I cannot move my right arm, I can't tell if movement makes it worse, and changing positions doesn't help.
Have you ever experienced similar symptoms in the past, in the same or different limbs?
No, this has never happened before.

Considering your profession as a waiter with repetitive arm use, the acute onset of severe pain and immobility without apparent injury or associated symptoms, and the absence of neck pain, cardiovascular, or neurological symptoms, the condition may be related to a musculoskeletal disorder.

**Final Diagnosis:** Acute brachial plexus neuritis (Parsonage-Turner Syndrome) or a severe strain/sprain from overuse with possible nerve involvement.

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A 37-year-old male waiter presents to the clinic with severe pain in his right arm that started after waking up one morning. He mentions feeling extremely tired and is unable to keep his eyes open after night shifts. He has not taken any medications or tried any treatments, and denies any swelling, redness, or warmth in the affected arm. Additionally, he has no history of heart disease and has never experienced this type of pain before.
trial_0.multiturn_frq: **Final Diagnosis:** Acute right arm paralysis likely due to a neurological cause; immediate referral to emergency care for further evaluation is warranted.
trial_0.singleturn_frq: Final Diagnosis: Right arm paralysis with severe pain.

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have severe pain in my right arm and I can't move it at all.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I've been experiencing these symptoms for 3 days.
Did you experience any trauma or injury to your arm or neck before the symptoms started?
No, the symptoms started after I woke up one morning, having slept on my side.
Are you experiencing any numbness or tingling in your arm, or any changes in your grip strength?
Yes, I have no sensation to light touch over my entire right arm and forearm.
Do you have any neck pain or stiffness?
No, I don't have any neck pain or stiffness.
Do you have any medical conditions or are you currently on any medication?
I'm otherwise healthy and not on any medication.

Are you experiencing any difficulty with breathing or changes in your voice, like hoarseness?
No, I am not experiencing any difficulty with breathing or changes in my voice.

No, I haven't noticed any changes in my ability to walk or maintain my balance.
Do you have any muscle wasting or atrophy in your arm or hand?
The vignette provided does not mention muscle wasting or atrophy, so I cannot confirm that.

Considering the acute onset following sleep, with complete motor paralysis, loss of sensation, and without neck pain or evidence of trauma, a possible diagnosis might be acute brachial plexus neuropathy (Parsonage-Turner syndrome). However, without further examination and diagnostic tests like imaging and electromyography, other conditions cannot be excluded.

**Final Diagnosis:** Suspected Parsonage-Turner syndrome (acute brachial plexus neuropathy).

I've been dealing with severe pain in my right arm for three days, and I can't move it at all.
Have you experienced any injuries or trauma to your arm recently?
No, the pain started after I woke up one morning, having slept on my side.
